questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.code: let variable: (mut &str, u32) = ("hello", 65000);
questions.a: Yes
questions.b: No, 65000 is too high for the u32 type
questions.c: No, 'hello' is not of the type &str
questions.d: No, it is not possible to have mut before the type in a tuple

questions.question: Does the following code compile ? (other_variable = 10)
questions.code: let var = if other_variable == 5 {10};
questions.a: Yes
questions.b: No, it is impossible to determine the type of var
questions.c: No, it is forbidden to write if statements this way
questions.d: No, the return keyword is missing before the 10

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.code: let array = [10; 20];
questions.a: Yes, it creates an array of 10 elements with the value 20
questions.b: Yes, it creates an array of 20 elements with the value 10
questions.c: Yes, it creates an array with two items 10 and 20
questions.d: No, the data type of the array items must be specified

questions.question: Is the following code a `binding` in Rust and what is the most correct definition of a `binding` ?
questions.a: The example code is a binding, it binds some values to names, the left-side is called a `pattern`.
questions.b: The example code is a binding, it is used to declare variables.
questions.c: The example code is not a binding, it binds some values to names, the left-side is called a `pattern`.
questions.d: The example code is not a binding, it is used to declare variables.

questions.question: How is removed the vector from the heap memory ?
questions.a: The vector is not allocated on the heap
questions.b: The pointer to the vector is removed from the stack, the heap content is not deleted
questions.c: Both of the pointer to the vector on the stack and the heap contant are deleted
questions.d: A garbage collector has to be manually executed to remove the heap content

questions.question: Why using the = operator on a vector moves it and using the same operator on an unsigned integer copies it ?
questions.a: Move semantics does not work on unsigned integers and floats
questions.b: Primitive data types implement the Copy trait
questions.c: Unsigned integer is not a primitive data type

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.a: No, a value has been borrowed by b, the value cannot be borrowed anymore in the current scope
questions.b: No, it is not allowed to have two bindings to the same variable (a and b)
questions.c: Yes, a is equal to 20 at the end
questions.d: Yes, a is equal to 50 at the end

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.a: No, a cannot be declared two times
questions.b: No, it is not allowed to shadow a variable if it has been borrowed in the current scope
questions.c: No, it is not allowed to shadow a variable if the borrowing reference is mutable but allowed if the borrowing reference is immutable

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.code: fn foo<'a>(value: &'a u32) {}
questions.a: No, a function cannot be empty
questions.b: No, lifetimes cannot be part of the function <> parameters
questions.c: Yes, 'a is the lifetime of the reference value
questions.d: Yes, 'a is the lifetime of the foo method

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.code: fn foo<'a>(value: &'a mut u8) {}
questions.a: No, references with lifetimes cannot be mutable
questions.b: No, lifetimes cannot be part of the function <> parameters
questions.c: Yes, 'a is the lifetime of the foo method
questions.d: Yes, 'a is the lifetime of the reference value

questions.question: Does the following code compile ?
questions.a: Yes
questions.b: No, a lifetime is mandatory for structure variables that are references
questions.c: No, a structure cannot contains references
questions.d: No, a structure cannot contains only one variable as it makes no sense
